questions.text: Which of the following factor in PC VS time graph is a measure of extent of drug absorption of a drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Area under the Curve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option D - Tmax - time taken to reach max concentration - correlates with Rate of absorption. Option C - Cmax - maximum concentration at a given dose – correlates with maximum concentration achieved at any dose. Option B - Half Life – time taken for half the drug to eliminate – correlates with rate of elimination. Area under the curve gives us the extent of drug absorption.

questions.text: Manufacturer of a drug company labels the drug contains 500 mg Paracetamol. On quantitative analysis by the authorities, it was found to contain only 200 mg of drug. According to drugs and cosmetics act 1940, this type of drug is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Misbranded Drug Misbranded drug: Any wrong information on the label or in other words, any drug for which the label is in any way false or misleading. Such conduct as set forth in paragraphs (1) and (2) of the Findings of Fact Section constitutes a violation of section 3715.64(A).

Highyeild:

Characteristics of Misbranded drugs in India Not labelled in the prescribed manner Colored, coated & polished that damage is concealed Appears better and of greater therapeutic value than what actually is Label or container accompanying the drugs bears statement which makes false claim for the drug and which is misleading

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Spurious drug: Mimicking drug of a well reputed producer Spurious or imitation drug products are drug formulations manufactured concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product. The product may or may not contain the active ingredients. Option B - Adulterated drug: Substituting original crude drug with other similar looking substances A drug or device shall be deemed to be adulterated if it is a drug and any substance has been (i) mixed or packed with it so as to reduce its quality or strength or (ii) substituted wholly or in part for it. Option C - No term such as unethical drug exists

Table:

#MANTRA Misbranded drugs. - Label related to Warning Directions to use Claim if it is not labelled in the prescribed manner; or if its label or container or anything accompanying the drug design or device which makes any false claim for the drug or which is false or misleading in any particular. if it is so coloured, coated, powdered or polished that damage is concealed or if it is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is;

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the given graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Drug A represent agonist and Drug B represents inverse agonist

options.label: B
options.text: Drug C represents agonist and Drug D is inverse agonist

options.label: C
options.text: Drug A is agonist and Drug D is inverse agonist

options.label: D
options.text: Drug B is partial agonist and Drug C is inverse agonist

questions.correct_answer: C. Drug A is agonist and Drug D is inverse agonist
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drug A is agonist and Drug D is inverse agonist Graph shows percentage of Maximum activity or intrinsic activity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - drug B is not inverse agonist , it is partial agonist. Partial agonists have a lower intrinsic activity at receptors than full agonists, allowing them to act either as a functional agonist or a functional antagonist, depending on the surrounding levels of naturally occurring neurotransmitter (full agonist). Option B - drug C do not have any activity irrespective of the ligand concentration - so it is not likely to be an agonist. Option D - drug C do not have any activity irrespective of the ligand concentration - so it is not likely to be a partial agonist. Based on this there are 4 types of intrinsic activity given the graph: Agonist 1 Partial Agonist 0-1 Antagonist 0 Inverse Agonist -ve Drug A has maximum activity and Drug D is negative hence Option C is the correct answer.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Competitive The given graph is a LINEWEAVER BURKE PLOT between 1/V and 1/S

Highyeild:

Competitive inhibition is interruption of a chemical pathway owing to one chemical substance inhibiting the effect of another by competing with it for binding or bonding. An example of a competitive inhibitor is the antineoplastic drug methotrexate. Methotrexate has a structure similar to that of the vitamin folic acid. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, preventing the regeneration of dihydrofolate from tetrahydrofolate. Noncompetitive inhibition, a type of allosteric regulation, is a specific type of enzyme inhibition characterized by an inhibitor binding to an allosteric site resulting in decreased efficacy of the enzyme. An allosteric site is simply a site that differs from the active site- where the substrate binds. The inhibitory effects of heavy metals, and of cyanide on cytochrome oxidase and of arsenate on glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase, are examples of non-competitive inhibition. This type of inhibitor acts by combining with the enzyme in such a way that for some reason the active site is rendered inoperative. In Competitive inhibition Vmax remains the same while Km changes In noncompetitive inhibition Km remains the same while Vmax changes Reversible uncompetitive inhibition occurs when (I) binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex (ES) and not free E. One can hypothesize that on binding S, a conformational change in E occurs which presents a binding site for I. Inhibition occurs since ESI cannot form product. In un competitive inhibition both Km and Vmax remains different.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A 20 year old boy was brought to emergency room after consuming some unknown substance. The patient was sweating profusely, saliva was drooling from mouth and tears were present. The boy suffered involuntary urination and diarrhea. On examination, the heart rate was 58 beats per minutes and blood pressure was 80/60 mm hg. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropine This clinical scenario is suggestive of Mushroom poisoning or Organophosphate poisoning with cholinergic symptoms. Atropine is the DOC in organophosphate poisoning. Antidotes: Atropine – OP poisoning N acetylcysteine – Paracetamol overdose Naloxone – Opiod poisoning Physostigmine - Atropine Organophosphate poisoning permanently block the AchE and thus increase Ach which leads to various muscarinic effects M1: Increases gastric HCl M2 : CVS effects🡪decreases HR and BP M3 : Pinpoint pupils, Increased secretions (Severe diarrhea), Urinary incontinence, Broncho-constriction . <

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - NAC - N-acetylcysteine is a medication used to treat conditions such as asthma and cystic fibrosis. As an inhalant, it helps to thin mucus and make it less paste-like. It also reduces inflammation. N-acetylcysteine is byproduct of glutathione . Option C - naloxone - Naloxone, sold under the brand name Narcan among others, is a medication used to reverse the effects of opioids. It is commonly used to counter decreased breathing in opioid overdose. Effects begin within two minutes when given intravenously, and within five minutes when injected into a muscle. Option D - Physostigmine is a medication most commonly used to manage and treat antimuscarinic toxicity and glaucoma. It is a tertiary amine and a reversible cholinergic medication most commonly used to manage and treat antimuscarinic toxicity and glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the primary treatment agent in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azathioprine

Highyeild:

DMARD Use with Hepatic Disease Contraindicated with Hepatic Disease ● MTX ● Leflunomide ● NSAIDS ● Acetaminophen ● Azathioprine ● Sulfasalazine Contraindicated with HBV ● Rituximab ● TNF inhibitors ● Abatacept Probably Safe in HCV ● Glucocorticoids ● Hydroxychloroquine ● TNF inhibitors ● Gold Salts ● Mycophenolate ● Cyclosporine Common DMARDs include methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, others), leflunomide (Arava), hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) and sulfasalazine (Azulfidine). Side effects vary but may include liver damage and severe lung infections. Azathioprine is an immune suppressive agent and is rarely used in RA.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - DOC in RA (rheumatoid arthritis) is Methotrexate. Methotrexate is one of a group of medications called disease‐modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and it is the most common treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate helps prevent further permanent damage that can happen if rheumatoid arthritis is not treated. Option B - DOC in RA during pregnancy is Hydroxychloroquine Hydroxychloroquine has been available since the 1970s and is used widely for the treatment of lupus (SLE) but is also an established drug for the treatment of mild RA. It is commonly used in combination with one or two other disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs), particularly methotrexate. Option C - Sulfasalazine is second line drug in RA. Sulfasalazine, sold under the trade name Azulfidine among others, is a medication used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis, and Crohn's disease. It is considered by some to be a first-line treatment in rheumatoid arthritis. It is taken by mouth. Significant side effects occur in about 25% of people.

Table:

#MANTRA Classification A. Synthetic DMARDS 1. Methotrexate 2. Azathioprine 3. Cyclophosphamide 4. Cyclosporine 5. Chloroquine 6. Hydroxychloroquine 7. Sulphasalazine 8. Leflunomide 9. Gold salts 10. d-penicillamine B. Biological DMARDs a) TNF a antagonist 1. Etanercept 2. Infliximab 3. adalimumab b) IL-1 antagonist 1. Anakinra c) T-cell modulating agents Abatacept d) B-lympho depletor 1. Rituximab 2. Methyl prednisolone

questions.text: Identify the correct match regarding the drug and its adverse drug reaction?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Verapamil: Constipation Verapamil, sold under various trade names, is a calcium channel blocker medication used for the treatment of high blood pressure, angina, and supraventricular tachycardia. It may also be used for the prevention of migraines and cluster headaches. It is given by mouth or by injection into a vein.

Highyeild:

Side Effects Blue lips and fingernails. chest pain. coughing that sometimes produces a pink frothy sputum. difficult, fast, noisy breathing, sometimes with wheezing. dizziness, faintness, or light-headedness when getting up from a lying or sitting position suddenly. light-headedness, dizziness, or fainting. shortness of breath.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Hydralazine is a vasodilator use in treatment of Heart failure. Hydralazine, sold under the brand name Apresoline among others, is a medication used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. This includes high blood pressure in pregnancy and very high blood pressure resulting in symptoms. Side effects - flushing headache upset stomach vomiting loss of appetite diarrhea constipation eye tearing Verapamil is a CCB hence decreases GI motility and causes constipation. Option C - Aliskiren is Renin inhibitor which will potentially cause hyperkalemia. Aliskiren is a renin inhibitor. It works by blocking an enzyme in the body that is necessary to produce a substance that causes blood vessels to tighten. As a result, the blood vessels relax and this decreases the blood pressure. Side effects are - Diarrhea Stomach Pain Heartburn Cough Rash Dizziness Headache Back Pain Option D - Methyldopa causes hemolytic anemia. Methyldopa is used to treat high blood pressure. Methyldopa is in a class of medications called antihypertensives. It works by relaxing the blood vessels so that blood can flow more easily through the body. Side effects - Headache Muscle Weakness Swollen Ankles Or Feet Upset Stomach Vomiting Diarrhea Gas Dry Mouth

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: From the given diagram, identify the possible mechanism of action and correct option for isoniazid ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drug A

Highyeild:

Side effects of isoniazid Peripheral neuropathy : CNS excitement INH→ Vit B 6 ↓→ GABA↓→ CNS excitement seen in slow acetylation, Vit B 6 prevention hepatic injury acetylated products-monoacetyl isoniazid (liver toxic) seen in rapid acetylation, hepatic function test needed Isoniazid is a pro-drug which is metabolized by catalyse-peroxidase enzyme to active product which then inhibits mycolic acid in bacterial cell wall. This enzyme is produced by Kat G gene. Hence Drug A is isoniazide.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Drug B is Ethambutol inhibiting Arabinogalactum n bacterial cell wall. Option C - Drug C is Pyrazinamide Option D - Drug D is Bedaquiline inhibiting ATP Synthase Drug E is rifampicin acting on RNA polymerase Drug F is streptomycin inhibiting protein synthesis.

Table:

Injectable anti-TB drugs Streptomycin (First line) Kanamycin, Amikacin, Capreomycin Group 3. Fluoroquinolones Ofloxacin, Levofloxacin Moxifloxacin Group 4. Oral bacteriostatic second-line anti-TB drugs Ethionamide, Prothionamide Cycloserine, Terizidone Para-amino salicylic acid Group 5. questions.text: Pregnant female with history of lepromatous leprosy presents to OPD with type 2 lepra reaction. What should be the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Add Corticosteroids

Highyeild:

Type 2 lepra reaction - Type 2 lepra reaction is an inflammatory systemic reaction in which immune complexes can deposit in any organ or tissue and can have varied presentations. Neuritis, orchitis, uveitis, periostitis, lymphadenitis, and glomerulonephritis can occur rarely. Never stop MDT in pregnancy. Anti-inflammatory agents are to be added hence corticosteroids needs to be added.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Thalidomide is not safe in pregnancy. Thalidomide is highly effective in the treatment of patients with chronic or recurrent ENL. It acts by inhibition of selective gene expression of tumour necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) involved in the pathogenesis of nerve damage in leprosy and other mechanisms contributing to its anti-inflammatory effect Option B - MDT is not stopped in this - Treatment for severe type 2 lepra reactions may include: Prednisone at a dose of about 1 mg/kg/day, quickly tapered. Clofazimine (note that the multibacillary regimen with clofazimine prevents type 2 lepra reactions) Thalidomide 400 mg/day for 5–10 days, tapered over 1–2 months. Option D - Hansen's disease is treated with a combination of antibiotics. Typically, 2 or 3 antibiotics are used at the same time. These are dapsone with rifampicin, and clofazimine is added for some types of the disease.

Solution:

4-Hydroxy Cyclophosphamide Cyclophosphamide is an anti cancer agent. It is metabolized to 4-OH-Cyclophosphamide which is an isomer to aldophosphamide. Both of this metabolites are active substances. This also produces Acrolein which causes cystitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - this is incorrect as it is 4 - hydroxy and the option has 4 - ketoacyl. Option C - not the correct option - as - Option D -

questions.text: Immune checkpoint inhibitor approved for treatment of advanced endometrial carcinoma is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pembrolizumab

Highyeild:

Immune check point inhibitors are monoclonal antibodies produced against PD-I, PD-L, CTLA which are used by cancer cells to evade T lymphocytes. Cetuximab is monoclonal antibody against EGFR used in colorectal ca, Head and neck Ca. Pembrolizumab, Atezolizumab, Nivolumab are all immune check point inhibitors. Cetuximab, sold under the brand name Erbitux, is an epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitor medication used for the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer. Cetuximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody given by intravenous infusion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Pembrolizumab, sold under the brand name Keytruda, is a humanized antibody used in cancer immunotherapy that treats melanoma, lung cancer, head and neck cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, stomach cancer, cervical cancer, and certain types of breast cancer. It is given by slow injection into a vein. Atezolizumab, sold under the brand name Tecentriq, is a monoclonal antibody medication used to treat urothelial carcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer, triple-negative breast cancer, small cell lung cancer, and hepatocellular carcinoma. Option B - Nivolumab is used alone or with other drugs to treat certain types of esophageal cancer, gastroesophageal junction cancer, stomach cancer, colorectal cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, renal cell carcinoma (a type of kidney cancer), melanoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (a type of liver cancer), squamous cell carcinoma . Option C - Ipilimumab are used against CTLA in malignant melanoma Multiple drugs are produced against PD-I/PD-L: Pembrolizumab- Widest spectrum Nivolumab – Urothelial Ca Atezolizumab- Urothelial Ca Cemuplimumab – SCC of skin Option D - Trastuzumab, sold under the brand name Herceptin among others, is a monoclonal antibody used to treat breast cancer and stomach cancer. It is specifically used for cancer that is HER2 receptor positive. It may be used by itself or together with other chemotherapy medication.

questions.text: A young boy earlier diagnosed as schizophrenia was taking some antipsychotic medication. He presented to casualty with sudden twisting of neck muscles, tremulousness of hands, stiffening of fingers, protrusion of tongue, he is frightened and restless. You are in the casualty, how will you manage the patient-

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure the attendants that the patient has nothing serious and is just a dissociative symptoms

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give IV Promethazine

Highyeild:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of oculogyric crisis and thus Promethazine is the most adequate management for this scenario. Oculogyric crisis refers to the spasm of the extraocular muscles. usually causing upward and outward deviation of the eyes and is a severe form of acute dystonia; an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics like Risperidone. It can be treated by antimuscarinic drugs (subtype of anticholinergic drugs) like promethazine. Dystonia is acute in onset and occurs within 1-5 days of starting treatment It is more common in the younger population. The proposed mechanism of action is D2 blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway. There is typical involvement of head and neck muscles and presents in a variety of forms such as torticollis, trismus, mouth opening dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria, oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm and swallowing difficulties. Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic with D2 blocking but strong 5HT2 antagonistic activity. Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and thus, its adverse effects include sedation, light-headedness, confusional state, weight gain, etc. Olanzapine is also an atypical antipsychotic. Its adverse effects are dry mouth, constipation, weight gain, impaired glucose tolerance etc.

Extraedge:

Its main side effects include metabolic effects like: Weight Gain, Hyperglycemia, Hyperprolactinemia Dyslipidemia, Etc. At low doses. extrapyramidal side effects are less but can become prominent when the drug is given in higher doses. Extrapyramidal side effects include:

Table:

#MANTRA Extrapyramidal side effects include:

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not indicated in treatment of sickle cell anemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bebtelovimab Bebtelovimab binds the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein with a dissociation constant KD = 0.046 - 0.075 nM and blocks spike protein attachment to the human ACE2 receptor with an IC50 value of 0.39 nM.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C - Hydroxyurea: Hydroxyurea has an "anti-sickling" effect via induction of fetal hemoglobin Improves RBC hydration Reduces leucocyte adhesion Reduces pro-inflammatory markers Acts as NO donor, promoting vasodilation Voxelator: Increases the oxygen affinity of HbS by inhibiting HbS polymeration L-Glutamine: Acts by inhibiting the P-Selectin antioxidant Bebtelovimab: A new monoclonal antibody for the treatment of COVID-19 that retains activity against the Omicron variant. Bebtelovimab works by binding to the spike protein of the virus that causes COVID-19 Bebtelovimab is approved for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 in adults and pediatric patients ( >12 years) with a positive COVID-19 test, and who are at high risk for progression to severe COVID-19, including hospitalization or death L-glutamine is a naturally occurring amino acid. Although the mechanism of action for L-glutamine is not fully understood, its use in sickle cell disease is based on its antioxidant activity. It increases NAD redox potential in sickle red blood cells through increasing the availability of reduced glutathione. The net effect of morphine is the activation of descending inhibitory pathways of the CNS as well as inhibition of the nociceptive afferent neurons of the PNS, which leads to an overall reduction of the nociceptive transmission.
